name: Engineering Student Council
summary: Leading and representing the undergraduate student body of the College of Engineering (CoE) through supporting engineering student groups, facilitating CoE discussion, and connecting students/RSOs with resources.

name: Environmental Engineering Society
summary: EES is the student chapter of the Air & Waste Management Association (AWMA) at MSU. We are a professional organization that holds presentations on various topics within the broad environmental engineering field. Our club is a great way to hear about hot topics within the environmental engineering, meet professionals within the industry, learn about career opportunities, and create great connections.

name: Biomedical Engineering Society
summary: Promote the profession of biomedical engineering through the organized effort of this group in the study, research, and discussion of the fields of biomedical engineering, and the dissemination of the knowledge thereby gained.

name: Greek Engineering Society
summary: The Greek Engineering Society at Michigan State University is a dynamic organization dedicated to fostering a strong community among engineering students within fraternities and sororities. Our mission is to promote professional development, social engagement, and interdisciplinary collaboration among our members. We offer a unique platform for members to connect with industry professionals, participate in networking events, and develop both technical and soft skills through workshops, guest speakers, and hands-on projects. Our society is open to students from the College of Engineering, Packaging, Data Analytics, IT, and Lyman Briggs, ensuring a diverse and inclusive environment. Membership is by invitation from a regional delegate and requires a minimum 2.5 GPA and active participation in monthly meetings. Through a blend of professional development opportunities and social activities, we aim to prepare our members for successful careers while building lasting friendships and network

name: Software Engineering in Computer Science
summary: The Software Engineering and Computing Society at MSU is dedicated to espousing and developing good software engineering habits and principles as a skill that can be developed – we hope to find like minded individuals interested in creating awesome solutions using computers to hard problems. Come check us out if that sounds like you!

name: Biosystems Engineering Club
summary: Club meetings on Mondays 6:30-7:30PM in Farrall 119.

name: Society of Applied Engineering Sciences
summary: Society of Applied Engineering Sciences (SAES) hosts various meetings with companies and alumni throughout the year. During those meetings, members learn more about that company's internship and full-time opportunities while also making a new connection with that company. Along with that, members gain new insight on what the job market looks like for their major and skills and learn how to be successful in their field. The meetings with alumni give insight on how the transition from college to work looks like in the field. As the Applied Engineering Sciences (AES) major is half engineering and half business, the opportunities are endless. SAES will help students to explore all of the career opportunities that can be given with the AES major. The alumni network for AES is very involved in aiding students to succeed in their job search. Alumni office hours, hosted by SAES, will have AES alumni who are willing to answer any questions that students have about their professional development

name: Materials Science and Engineering Society
summary: The Material Science and Engineering Society is a undergraduate-run organization that provides students pursuing MSE with engineering projects, resources for studying, and access to alumni and representatives in industry.

name: Biomedical Engineering Graduate Student Association
summary: Primary activities of the BME GSA include graduate student engagement in the BME Department, social and career development events, coordination with BME Department faculty, and graduate student representation in BME Department matters.

name: American Indian Science and Engineering Society
summary: The vision of the American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) is for the next seven generations of Native people to be successful, respected, influential, and contributing members of our vast and ever-changing global community. We will have bi-weekly meetings to promote opportunities that benefit organizational members. The group will also work to attend the national AISES Conference.

name: Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers
summary: The Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE) at Michigan State University (MSU) changes lives by empowering the Hispanic community to realize its fullest potential and to impact the world through STEM awareness, access, support and development. MSU SHPE strives to provide the Hispanic community in STEM related fields with opportunities that will improve their academic, leadership, and professional abilities. Regardless of background, we encourage ALL to join!

name: Society of Women Engineers, MSU Chapter
summary: The Society of Women Engineers is a national organization where we empower women in engineering. At our biweekly meetings we welcome companies to present to us on professional development related topics. We also engage in social and outreach events.

name: Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers
summary: To prepare Asian heritage scientists and engineers for the professional world, celebrate diversity, and help local communities.

name: Engineers for a Sustainable World - Michigan State University
summary: The goal of the Michigan State University (MSU) Chapter of Engineers for a Sustainable World (ESW) is to combine engineering skills with an understanding of environmental issues to create valuable solutions to worldwide problems.

name: American Society of Civil Engineers
summary: Welcome to the MSU student chapter of the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE). We are a professional club with the goal on introducing students to the many things a Civil Engineer can do through company meetings and networking events. We try to meet a couple times a month with Engineering firms from around the state. If you have interest in joining, please visit our website for membership information.

name: Engineers Without Borders, MSU
summary: EWB-MSU is a student organization that works to implement sustainable engineering designs in developing countries. The mission of EWB-MSU is to improve the quality of life of less fortunate communities. Our student organization is a great opportunity for students to apply classroom knowledge to real-world problems. We currently have an international service project with the community of Buyuni, Tanzania where students plan to design and implement a rainwater catchment system for a local school. Our chapter has also assisted the Detroit Professional chapter with their project in El Balsamar, El Salvador to provide engineering solutions to health & sanitation issues. We do local community service in the East Lansing area every month. We also host an alternate spring break program to aid communities across the USA. The group gives students the opportunity to volunteer, network with professionals, meet new people, develop leadership and problem-solving skills, and improve the world! Our or

name: Audio Enthusiasts and Engineers
summary: AEE is a student organization that has a high level of interest in audio equipment and music. Founded in 2006, AEE's members use their skills to research, design, and build personalized audio equipment, as well as creating music.

name: Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers
summary: Michigan State University's IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) Student Branch is a student community within the world's largest technical professional organization dedicated to advancing technology. Our branch provides students with opportunities to enhance their technical knowledge, develop professional skills, and engage in meaningful networking and collaboration within the field of electrical engineering, computer science, data science, and computer engineering.

name: National Society of Black Engineers
summary: NSBE MSU is a flourishing organization. Our chapter boasts more than 50 members annually and a chapter GPA of +3.0. We strive to be one of the most prominent groups on campus and one of the strongest NSBE chapters in Region IV. We offer a wide range of programs to our membership and the MSU community. Programming efforts focus on academic and technical excellence, professional development, community service, networking, and social activities. Join Today!

name: American Society of Mechanical Engineers
summary: ASME at Michigan State is committed to providing students and faculty with a connection to the engineering profession outside of the classroom. ASME provides a great opportunity to learn about different companies, meet fellow students, and much more.

name: ASCE Geotech, MSU
summary: MSU ASCE Geotech is a student-led organization dedicated to fostering interest and advancing knowledge in the field of Geotechnical Engineering. Open to both undergraduate and graduate students, this organization provides a collaborative platform for individuals passionate about geotechnical topics, from soil mechanics to foundations, geotechnical design, and beyond. Through a variety of activities, including guest lectures, hands-on projects, field trips, and participation in regional and national geotechnical competitions, members will have the opportunity to engage with professionals in the industry, enhance their technical skills, and build lasting connections within the geotechnical community. Whether you’re looking to deepen your understanding of geotechnical principles, collaborate on exciting projects, or network with industry leaders, MSU ASCE Geotech offers a supportive environment for all students interested in pursuing careers in Geotechnical Engineering. Join us and help s

name: Institute of Transportation Professionals
summary: ITE is a professional group of transportation driven individuals whether it be planning, engineering, data science, and so many others. We hold events for students like networking, social, and work with other groups such as ASCE on such events.

name: American Institute of Chemical Engineers
summary: We are a professional organization for chemical engineering students at MSU. We aim to connect students with employers through company meetings, improve their career profile through resume critiques, and provide an environment to build friendships.

name: Association for Computing Machinery
summary: Whether you're completely new to programming or simply can't wait to get out of college, we're here to aid you and your computer science goals. We host tech talks and workshops presented by companies all across the nation; some that have presented in the past include Google, Microsoft, Ford, Quicken Loans, Target, Mozilla, and many more. We have more plans to announce very soon, so please join the ACM Discord server to stay up to date!

name: Women in Computing, MSU
summary: Women in Computing (WIC) at Michigan State University is a student-led organization dedicated to empowering women and gender-diverse students in technology. Our mission is to foster an inclusive community that supports academic, professional, and personal growth through mentorship, technical workshops, networking opportunities, outreach initiatives, and leadership development. We work to bridge the gender gap in computing by inspiring the next generation of technologists and building meaningful connections with industry partners.

name: Precision Agriculture Robotics Club
summary: The Precision Agriculture Robotics Club (PARC) constructs a new fully autonomous robot every year to compete in the robotics competition at the ASABE conference. To do this the club make use of engineering knowledge from a wide variety of disciplines to tackle the unique challenges of the competition for that year.

name: STrength Augmenting Robotic eXoskeleton Team
summary: Exo-suits have been popularized by icons such as Iron Man and STARX wishes to make a suit like his into a reality. STARX comprises of engineering students of all backgrounds who specialize in the exo-suit's bio-mechanics, electronics, programming, and actuation. STARX is involved in cutting edge research and allows students to experience enterprise level engineering design opportunities not available in the classroom such as 3D printing, advanced machining and programming, and artificial muscle design and implementation.

name: Cultivate Network
summary: A Church of communities embedded in East Lansing and rooted alongside Michigan State's campus.

name: Society of Automotive Engineers Formula Racing Team
summary: The MSU Formula Racing Team designs, builds, tests, and competes a brand-new race car from the ground-up every year to compete against over 550 universities worldwide in the world's largest collegiate design series—Formula SAE. The team gives students from all majors, backgrounds, and skill levels the opportunity to apply classroom principles to real-life engineering, project management, and business problem solving scenarios. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A5au4JV3m5Q&feature=youtu.be

name: Market Research Group
summary: At the beginning of each meeting, students may propose events they deem worthy of discussing at the next week's meeting. After the meeting, these events will be voted on by the organization's members to determine what we will discuss in the next meeting (2-3 events). Once determined, students will have the rest of the week to look into these events and formulate any questions, comments hypotheses, or more they'd like to bring up. Sector analysts will lead research and give a quick high-level overview of the event before opening the floor to group discussion. Analysts and eboard will help facilitate the conversation while encouraging others to share their thoughts. Students are encouraged to send any quotes, charts, or pictures that they find interesting to the eboard so they can be shown while discussing said topic. Additionally, we will bring in professionals and professors to speak on the issues at hand and share their thoughts. We aim to help improve students' research and interpers

name: Fisheries and Wildlife Graduate Student Organization
summary: The Fisheries and Wildlife GSO operates department activities, enterprises and seminars that help formulate the necessary skills for success.

name: Baja SAE
summary: Baja SAE challenges students to design and build an off-road vehicle that will survive the severe punishment of rough terrain. As in real work situations, these students work together as a team to discover and resolve technical challenges in design, testing, and manufacturing. The most rugged of all the SAE competitions, Baja SAE also gives students the first-hand challenge of pursuing their passion while managing real-life demands and priorities. Each team's goal is to design and build a prototype of an all-weather, rugged, single-seat, off-road recreational vehicle that conforms to the rules set in place by SAE. 22-23 Season Recap Video

name: Rocketry, Michigan State University
summary: Every year members of the MSU Rocketry Team work in specialized sub groups to create the components of a high-powered rocket with which they compete in the Spaceport America Cup, an annual rocketry competition held in Midland, Texas

name: Bridges, MSU
summary: MSU Bridges seeks to provide opportunities for MSU students to tutor MSU staff in English and workplace skills in collaboration with REHS, Case Hall, and MSU faculty. The goal is for the staff to feel more confident in their English and workplace skills and for MSU students to learn from the MSU staff as well through their interactions.

name: Bridges International
summary: We are an organization for international and American students. By joining us, you can find friends from the US and around the world and find help adjusting to life in America and East Lansing. We describe ourselves as a Social network, Service, and a Spiritual resource. We have events throughout the semester. Once a week, we will meet for dinner and/or hangout. During the event you can make new friends, have meaningful discussion, and play fun games. Hope you can join us! https://youtu.be/o0nCkAMgFEE

name: Red Glasses Movement, Michigan State University Student Chapter
summary: This movement was started in honor of a young girl with Down syndrome, named Audrey Lou. Audrey unfortunately passed away in 2018 and has left a long legacy based around the motto living boldly, loving big, and passing It on. Our club wants to spread positivity and love to college students in such challenging times. We want to bridge the gap between kids and adults with Down syndrome and other similar conditions. We plan on fundraising for various charities that support individuals with Down syndrome and to create impactful experiences by volunteering with the charities we are supporting. Our mission is to utilize Audrey’s philosophy of life and to encourage others to do the same by ensuring that individuals of all disabilities feel loved and included.

name: Pasos de la Tierra Folkorica
summary: Our mission is to celebrate and preserve the rich cultural heritage of Mexico through dance while fostering inclusivity and representation at Michigan State University. By incorporating diverse folkloric styles from all of Mexico’s states and honoring the deep-rooted traditions of indigenous dances, including Danza Azteca, we aim to bring the powerful stories, vibrant colors, and rhythms of our culture to the MSU community. We are committed to creating a space where all MSU students feel valued and connected to their roots, history, and each other. In doing so, we strive to build a stronger, more inclusive environment where everyone, especially those far from home, can find belonging. We honor our ancestors, embrace our traditions, and believe that through dance, we can bridge cultures, uplift voices, and cultivate respect for the richness of Mexican and indigenous identities.

name: Pre-Street Medicine
summary: We are an undergraduate organization that helps local groups bridge the gap between healthcare and the homeless population.

name: Chinese-American Student Coalition
summary: The purpose of the Chinese-American Student Coalition is to foster an environment that supports Chinese-American students and those interested in Chinese culture, providing a space that bridges the divide between Chinese and American identities. We host a multitude of events including our Rice Night, Mid-Autumn Festival (including lantern painting and moon cakes), annual Lunar New Year banquet celebration, and more! For those interested in attending events, please follow our Instagram @msucsc for the most up-to-date announcements.

name: Chinese Learning Community
summary: We are a non-profit student organization with the goal of promoting learning about Chinese language and culture. We aim to build a bridge between Chinese learners and native speakers, facilitating the spread of knowledge outside of the classroom. We host in-person cultural & social events throughout the semester open to all MSU students with any level of interest and experience. 加油学习中文！

name: Spartan Sur
summary: Spartan Sur is Michigan State University's premier co-ed South Asian acapella team. Through the creation and performance of compositions that blend South Asian and Western styles, we strive to bridge the South Asian and acapella communities.

name: Balkan Student Society
summary: The purpose of the Balkan Student Society is to culminate an inclusive community on campus by providing a comforting space for Michigan State students who share a common cultural heritage to form connections with one another. Our aim is to establish an on campus community for Balkan students to engage, connect, support, and share their traditions with each other and the entirety of Michigan State University. We hope to bridge the gap between different communities and promote intercultural dialogue and appreciation. Ultimately, we aspire to create a sense of belonging for Balkan students at Michigan State, while promoting multiculturalism and diversity on campus.

name: W.E.B DuBois Society
summary: The W.E.B. Du Bois Society, founded in 1998 by Black students within James Madison College, is a vanguard organization dedicated to fostering a supportive community for Black students in public policy. Our mission is to empower and equip Black political thinkers with the tools, connections, and opportunities needed to influence and create equitable policies. We serve as a bridge to the broader Black political network, advocating for anti-discriminatory policies and fostering professional growth. We are committed to Building a supportive and inclusive community Empowering student voices Creating pathways to professional opportunities Encouraging collaboration and mentorship Championing equity and justice

name: MSU Bikes Service Center
summary: It started out in the spring of 2003 as a volunteer-run project and then received funding from the university to open its doors at the present location in the fall of 2006. MSU Bikes makes its home in the MSU Bikes Service Center, a full service bike shop on the campus of Michigan State University. It is a department under MSU Surplus & Recycling which is a division of MSU’s Infrastructure Planning and Facilities department. Michigan State University was upgraded in November 2015 as a silver level Bike Friendly University by the League of American Bicyclists. Read the MSU press release about the award here. Hours Open Mon: 10 am- 6 pm; Tues - Fri: 10 am-5 pm year-round (Except for University Holidays) History In the spring of 2003 Gus Gosselin, then director of Building Services for Infrastructure Planning and Facilities, and Terry Link, former director of the Office of Campus Sustainability, founded the MSU Bike Project. This all-volunteer effort was dedicated to transforming abandone

name: Reach Outside
summary: Do you enjoy working with kids? How about spending time outdoors? What about volunteering with kids in the outdoors?!?! If you said yes, consider joining REACH OUTSIDE!!!! We meet every other Tuesday at 6:30pm in Wells Hall. We are a registered student organization and nonprofit dedicated to providing opportunities for disadvantaged and underserved youth in the Lansing area to get involved in outdoor activities like rock climbing, skiing, snow tubing, canoeing and hiking. You do not have to have any experience doing these kinds of outdoor activities to join! Additionally, we want to encourage our participants to set goals, overcome challenges, gain confidence, exercise creativity and connect with positive mentors. There are so many health benefits to an outdoor and active lifestyle such as increased concentration, boosted mood and stress relief. However, many kids in East Lansing don't have exposure to the kinds of outdoor sports Michigan has to offer or the necessary means to particip

name: Motorcycle Racing Team, Michigan State University
summary: The purpose of this organization shall be to empower Michigan State University students to explore, design, build, and race motorcycles through hands-on engineering challenges, competitive racing, and industry engagement. The need of the organization is to fill a unique gap in the motorsport racing space focusing on high performance motorcycles and racing applications.

name: AIGA Student Professional Association
summary: AIGA (American Institute of Graphic Arts) is the largest national professional association for design. As the MSU student chapter, our focus is to connect graphic designers and creatives of all majors with one another to engage in professional development and build a peer-based support network for navigating the design world. Members of our chapter can expect to attend meetings like resume and internship workshops, industry events like lectures and portfolio reviews, and exclusive access to design projects and exhibition space. Our group builds a strong peer support network where designers connect, collaborate, and help each other grow. By building unique relationships within our community, we create space for opportunities, recommendations, and connections that extend beyond class and into employment. Meetings on Wednesdays in Kresge at 7pm! Find our socials, email-list, and more at: https://linktr.ee/msuaiga - Email: MichiganStateAIGA@gmail.com Instagram: @MichiganStateAIGA Facebook:

name: Muslim Tech Collaborative MSU
summary: The Muslim Tech Collaborative (MTC) at MSU is a student-led organization that empowers Muslim undergraduates and graduate students pursuing technology and engineering careers. We host hands-on workshops on topics ranging from web development and machine learning to cybersecurity best practices, alongside speaker panels featuring alumni and industry leaders. Through hackathons, team-based capstone projects and “code & chill” study sessions, members develop real-world skills in a supportive, faith-affirming environment. We meet twice weekly—on Tuesdays to explore technology through an Islamic lens with occasional guest speakers, and in a second session designed as an open coworking space for focused collaboration. Career-prep events—resume clinics, mock interviews and company office visits—help translate technical expertise into internship and job offers. By weaving Islamic values of ethics, social justice and community service into every event, MTC not only builds your résumé, but also

name: Spartan SynBio
summary: Spartan SynBio explores the cutting-edge world of genetic engineering and research to build an interdisciplinary team of students to talk with students about opportunities in synthetic biology and the job market. We host talks with industry experts from innovative biotech companies, educate members on foundational and advanced synthetic biology concepts, and prepare a team to compete in the prestigious iGEM competition. The iGEM is the most prestigious bioengineering/synthetic biology competition and here in Spartan SynBio we have the goal of winning the competition and bringing home the gold. We have opportunities for internships for research over the summer for those who are committed to our vision. Join us to design with DNA, network with pioneers, and drive the future of biology and bioengineering forward! The solutions we come up with here can affect change in the lives of many for the bettering of science.

name: Transfer Student Success Center (TSSC)
summary: The Transfer Student Success Center (TSSC) is an innovative space within the Transitions and Transfer Student Success designed to eliminate barriers to MSU transfer student success (i.e., time to graduation; retention) through a collaborative effort with internal and external partners.

name: buildOn Michigan State
summary: buildOn is an international non profit organization and its goal as an organization is to break the cycle of poverty, illiteracy, and low expectations through service and education. Our goal is to raise funds to donate, travel, and assist in building schools in underserved countries and empower students in the Lansing community to become leaders through education services and mentorship programs Our team at Michigan State University is a registered student organization (RSO) committed to furthering this mission by fundraising and advocating for global education initiatives. We are an independent student-led organization and not officially affiliated with Michigan State University. Our fundraising efforts directly support buildOn's initiatives, and we appreciate your support in making a difference!

name: Drone Research and Innovative Flight Technologies
summary: Michigan State University Drone Research and Innovative Flight Technology (DRIFT) is an award-winning student research group making profound progress in autonomous drone technology. With thousands of design and flight hours, DRIFT continues to build a strong reputation as a reliable platform for young engineers to apply and refine their technical skills. As a 2x NASA USRC recipient, DRIFT is expanding its roots to enrich the educational experience of countless students while continuing to develop cutting-edge solutions for vertical take-off and landing vehicles. By providing a safe and professional environment, all students are given the opportunity to apply their technical knowledge to critical projects with varying degrees of difficulty. Whether it's research, competition, or conventions, DRIFT challenges its researchers to continue pushing boundaries with UAVs. With the motto "Spartans Will" in mind, DRIFT works to represent MSU as a leader in our field with the tools for change. Ou

name: American Civil Liberties Union MSU COL Chapter
summary: Our purpose is to discuss, learn, and advance civil liberties on campus and off-campus. We host events on current social issues, encourage volunteer work in the community, and work with other MSU Law student organizations to raise awareness of civil liberties issues.

name: Chi Epsilon
summary: Chi Epsilon, the National Civil Engineering Honor Society, provides students (civil and environmental engineering) in the top third of their class with various opportunities, ranging from job/internship recruiting events to community service/volunteering. Being a member of Chi Epsilon also unlocks a network of other top civil/environmental engineering students and professionals alike, meaning mentorship and appeal from companies.

name: Middle Ground, MSU
summary: The purpose of the Michigan State University Middle Ground Club is to facilitate civil, productive conversations on various political topics. We aim to find common ground between differing political views, challenging members to think critically about issues and understand the perspectives that shape others’ beliefs. It will be a way to enhance critical thinking skills especially for understanding and solving complex and current political issues

name: Student Public Interest Research Group
summary: Students have the power to shape the future we will inherit. We work with professional staff at colleges and universities to make sure our peers have the skills, opportunities and training they need to create a better, more sustainable future for all of us. Our chapters and clubs on nearly 100 campuses in 25 states provide the training, professional support and resources students need to tackle climate change, protect public health, revitalize our democracy, feed the hungry and more. Students have been at the forefront of social change throughout history, from civil rights, to voting rights to protecting the environment. For nearly 50 years we’ve helped students to get organized, mobilized and energized so they can continue to be on the cutting edge of positive change.

name: Spartan Battalion Army ROTC
summary: The Spartan Battalion MSU RSO blends the Army Values of loyalty, duty, respect, selfless service, integrity and personal courage with the Spartan Values of individual strength, collective power and extraordinary achievement. The organization will not discriminate on the basis of age, color, gender, gender identity, disability status, height, marital status, national origin, political persuasion, race, religion, sexual orientation, veteran status, or weight. Also, only MSU students may be officers and/or voting members. All cadet fundraising activities will conform with the requirements of Cadet Command SOP, Procedure 0009 dated August 13, 2004. Fundraising activities will comply with the following: The Cadre Advisor and Professor of Military Science provide oversight of cadet fundraising activities. Cadre members will not engage in fundraising activities. Cadet fundraising activities may consist of donations, donations for goods or performance of services, and University sponsored fund

name: Mechanical Engineering Graduate Student Association
summary: The ME-GSA is all about connecting and empowering graduate students in the ME Department! We host social events, career development workshops, and collaborate with faculty to ensure grad student voices are heard. Our goal is to foster a supportive, inclusive, and vibrant community that helps students thrive academically, professionally, and personally. Our Mission : To create a space where Mechanical Engineering graduate students can build connections, develop their skills, and have their voices represented in department matters. Our Goals : Strengthen community and support among ME graduate students. Provide opportunities for professional development and career growth. Facilitate open communication between students and faculty. Advocate for the needs and concerns of the graduate student body. Meetings : We meet at least once every semester for general updates and planning, with additional events and socials throughout the semester. Get Involved : Joining is easy—if you're an ME gradua

name: Pi Tau Sigma
summary: Organization of high achieving Mechanical Engineering students designed to increase participation in academic, social, and service events with similarly-minded peers. We initiate the top-performing mechanical engineering juniors and seniors each semester.

name: Advanced Additive Manufacturing
summary: The purpose of this organization is to bring together like minded individuals who share an interest in additive manufacturing of polymers and polymer composites. We encourage all levels of experience to consider joining and to share your past and future projects for everyone to learn from. The organization includes topics in material science and chemical engineering, as well as mechanical and electrical engineering. Individuals with other backgrounds in modeling or art are also encouraged to join.

name: Bladesmithing, MSU
summary: The Bladesmithing Team at Michigan State is a group focused on teaching and applying engineering fundamentals to bladesmithing. The team consists mainly of material science and engineering undergraduates which leads to a focus on heat treatment, microstructure, and mechanical properties in the process of crafting a blade. The main goal of the team is to create a competition quality knife for the TMS Bladesmithing Competition that occurs every other year. The team has recently undergone a restart and plans on entering its first competition in 2026.

name: Amateur Radio Club
summary: The first radio station at Michigan State University was established through the efforts of the Amateur Radio Club in 1919 using the call letters of 8YG - broadcasting weather reports and farm market prices. In 1925 8YG became WKAR, the public broadcast station of Michigan State University, while a ham radio station was formed using the call letters 8XBU. In 1927 the call 8SH was issued to the amateur radio station. Today the MSU Amateur Radio Club operates W8SH and W8MSU from the campus in East Lansing. Please see our main website for more information on who we are, what we do, how to become a member, and about HAM radio in general: MSU Amateur Radio Club – Amateur Radio at Michigan State University You can also join our Discord page: https://discord.gg/MhWr3eefHE We would be happy to answer any questions you may have, and club members are frequently willing to meet and give tours of our 'shack' in Engineering Building room 2121.

name: Artificial Intelligence Club at Michigan State University
summary: We are a fast-growing club at Michigan State University driven by the passion and curiosity for one of the most promising branches of Computer Science: Artificial Intelligence. Our mission is to empower students with the knowledge of Artificial Intelligence through an inclusive environment that closes the gap between curiosity and hands-on practice in the field. We want to become Michigan State University’s hub for the learning and application of Artificial Intelligence among undergraduate students. Interested in becoming a member? Visit our website , where you can find more information about our club.

name: Imagine Software Club at MSU
summary: I nterested in becoming a member? Join our discord to receive updates on our next meeting information! Imagine Software Club Discord

name: Spartan Hackers
summary: Spartan Hackers exists to foster a community of technological innovation, collaboration, and creation at Michigan State University. About Us & What We Do? // Short Answer: A MSU CSE Club that Codes Projects to Get Money/Prizes/Internships and hosts the largest CS community. Hackathons The majority of what we do is go to Hackathons! Hackathons are 24-48 hour coding competitions and the fastest way to build real projects. While you're hacking, you can get to know representatives from companies like Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and more! Plus, every hackathon is filled to the brim with free food. Another plus, all hackathons we go to hand out prizes for winning projects. The highest 1st prize we've seen so far $10,000 CASH, but usually it's been a Nintendo Switch + $500 for each team member on average these days. Visit Devpost.com to see past Hackathons and projects! Workshops Spartan Hackers hosts events where students hang out, work on projects, share ideas, and learn about cool new tec

name: Unmanned Systems
summary: Join us as we compete in the collegiate drone competition known as SUAS (Small Unmanned Aerial Systems). Our goal is to design, build, and test a drone that can successfully complete the tasks required by the competition. All disciplines of engineering are welcome! If you are interested in jointing please reach out to one of the members of leadership! Meetings are Sunday at 12 in room 402 of the Computer Center.

name: Spartan Cybersecurity Club
summary: Spartan Cybersecurity Club is the cybersecurity and ethical hacking club at Michigan State University. We hold weekly meetings where we practice hands-on cybersecurity skills through Capture-The-Flag (CTF) challenges and discuss concepts related to cybersecurity. We also host workshops to teach ethical hacking skills, from Reverse Engineering to Car Hacking to Blockchain Security. Through collaboration with our industry partners, we hope to create an exciting and collaborative learning environment to prepare students for a career in cybersecurity. The Organization pursues the following goals: a) learn and promote ethical and responsible approach towards computer security; b) educate MSU students how to secure computer systems through learning the methods and tactics used by malicious attackers; c) practice the skills of penetration testing, security defense, and “white hat” (ethical) hacking; d) maintain awareness of the recent research in cybersecurity.

name: Information Science Club, MSU
summary: The MSU Information Science Club is a student led organization open to all majors. We welcome anyone interested in technology, design, data, media, and the impact of information on society. Our goal is to create a collaborative space where students can explore how tech shapes the world, from UX and privacy to policy and digital culture. We host speaker events, workshops, and networking opportunities to help members build practical skills, connect with professionals, and grow in their careers. Whether you're studying computer science, communication, or anything else in between, this club is a place to learn, share ideas, and most importantly get involved.

name: Michigan State University Information Technology
summary: Welcome to Michigan State University! We are Michigan State's Information Technology Department, more commonly known as MSU IT. Here are some things you need to know about the technology tools and services that MSU IT offers. You can also watch this video to get a download of everything that is important. GETTING STARTED AT MSU MSU NetID - your NetID is an electronic identity at MSU and serves as your login to many university applications and systems. How to get online - connecting to the MSU network, Internet & Wi-Fi. MSU Laptop Requirement - what you need and visit the MSU Tech Store for all of your technology needs. New Student Information - provides you with basic information to get you started with technology at MSU, including computer lab locations, common tools you’ll use to collaborate or support your coursework, how to print on campus, and more. TECH HELP & SUPPORT MSU IT is always here for support. Phone 517-432-6200 or toll free at (844) 678-6200 - call us from 7 a.m. to mid

name: Spartans Autonomous Racing Club
summary: The Spartan Autonomous Racing Club is a group for students who are passionate about the new technology being developed for all kinds of self-driving and unmanned vehicles. Our partnership with the Italian racing team Polimove in the Indy Autonomous Challenge gives us a front row seat to the advances in cutting-edge perception and controls software being deployed on professional racecars in the world's most competitive autonomous racing league. If you want to be a part of the future of autonomous driving, look no further.

name: Google Developer Groups
summary: Google Developer Groups is university based community group for students interested in Google developer technologies. Students who participate in GDG, grow their knowledge in peer-to-peer learning environments and build solutions for local businesses in their communities.

name: Official Pokemon GO Club
summary: MSU Pokémon GO is a club created to bring people together regarding the mobile game owned by The Pokémon Company, Nintendo and published by Augmented Reality (AR) software development company Niantic, "Pokémon GO." This server aims to encourage new friendships, support members of the organization, and to have fun. A big part of our goal is a focus on exploration, cooperation, and exercise.

name: MSU Tech Store
summary: The MSU Tech Store has been a technology staple of the Michigan State community for over thirty years. We specialize in technology consultations, so that Spartans can feel confident they're getting the best tech for their needs. The Tech Store also operates an in-person Help Desk to aid in diagnosing computer issues and work with our repair partners to fix broken and devices. We are Michigan State University’s on-campus technology store exclusively available to MSU students, faculty, and staff. You, as a member of the Spartan community, are able to take advantage of the stores' educational discounts, hands-on learning experiences, and services. We offer a wide range of tech products including computers , accessories , gaming equipment , software , and more. BACK TO SCHOOL SALE As part of our Back-To-School promotion, we’ve put together some deals that will help you hit the ground running this school year, including: Buy a Mac or iPad for college. Get AirPods. Save with education pricin

name: Aerospace Club
summary: To be a member of Aerospace Club, you must be a member of Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps (AFROTC) Detachment 380, a training program that prepares college students to become officers in the United States Air Force or United States Space Force. Students work with Det 380 to qualify for a commission while simultaneously completing their university undergraduate degree requirements.

name: Aviation and Aerospace Medicine Interest Group
summary: The Aviation and Aerospace Medicine Interest Group (AAMIG) at Michigan State University College of Human Medicine is a student-led organization dedicated to exploring the unique physiological and clinical challenges faced in aviation and space environments. As part of the Midwest Chapter of the Aerospace Medicine Student and Resident Organization (AMSRO), AAMIG aims to build awareness of aerospace medicine through speaker events, educational opportunities, and local community engagement. Our events so far have included a virtual discussion with a practicing flight surgeon and a volunteer initiative with Wings of Mercy, a nonprofit that provides free air transportation to patients in need. We welcome students of all backgrounds who are curious about the intersection of medicine, aviation, and human performance in extreme environments.

name: Air and Space Law Society at MSU
summary: MISSION STATEMENT: The ASLS is dedicated to advancing awareness, scholarship, and sustainability in air and space law. Through community engagement, academic exploration, and opportunities for personal and professional growth, the ASLS provides a platform for students to engage with the complex legal and policy challenges of the rapidly evolving aerospace sector. VISION STATEMENT: The Air and Space Law Society (ASLS) envisions a world where air and space are accessible, equitable, and sustainably governed through informed and innovative legal frameworks. We aspire to empower the next generation of aerospace leaders to shape a future where all can share the benefits of advancing air and space exploration and technology. CORE PRINCIPLES: The ASLS maintains the following principles. Members should seek to embody these values in their personal lives and professional endeavors. i. Integrity: Uphold honesty and accountability in all actions and decisions, guided by the principle of doing wha

name: SAMPE Michigan State University Student Chapter
summary: The SAMPE MSU Student Chapter is a professional student organization at Michigan State University dedicated to advancing knowledge, research, and career opportunities in advanced materials and processes. As part of the international Society for the Advancement of Material and Process Engineering (SAMPE), our chapter connects students with industry leaders, researchers, and innovators in aerospace, automotive, energy, and cutting-edge composite technologies. Our chapter also supports student participation in SAMPE conferences, design competitions, and scholarship opportunities, creating pathways for professional development and global collaboration. Membership is open to undergraduate and graduate students across all disciplines with an interest in materials, manufacturing, and innovation. Guided by faculty advisors and supported by industry partners, the SAMPE MSU Student Chapter fosters a community where Spartans can lead the future of advanced material and process engineering.

name: Biomedical Laboratory Diagnostics Student Association
summary: The Biomedical Laboratory Diagnostics Student Association (BLDSA) is a student led association that coordinates events for students to make connections, hear from guest speakers and ask questions about their experiences, and provides opportunities to participate in community service.

name: National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers
summary: NOBCChE intends to address the diverse needs and interests of chemistry and chemical engineering students; provide access to supports and job connections for students; and promote awareness of the various fields involved with STEM majors.

name: Omega Chi Epsilon
summary: Since the organization’s founding in 1931, Omega Chi Epsilon has recognized the academic merit and strong character of people in their junior or senior year of study in chemical engineering programs across the nation. To be considered for membership, juniors must rank in the upper 25% of their class and have a GPA of 3.25 or more. Seniors in the upper 33% must have a GPA of 3.0 or more to be eligible. They must also have completed at least one chemical engineering course. If you choose to join Omega Chi Epsilon, you will become part of an organization that stands for excellence in the field of chemical engineering. The Alpha Zeta chapter here at Michigan State University has participated in many activities. Our main event is tutoring for CHE 201 and CHE 210 students, but we also volunteer at various College of Engineering and STEM-related events.

name: Hybrid Athlete Association, Michigan State University
summary: The purpose of this organization is to promote a hybrid method of training that incorporates strength training, endurance training, nutrition, and recovery and understanding the science involved with both processes down to a chemical and biological level allowing for a deeper level of understanding within the bodily systems. We believe that a hybrid athlete is someone who prioritizes improvements in all aspects of their health. This perspective enables our members to not only enhance their physical capabilities through strength and endurance training but also to gain a profound insight into the underlying scientific principles that govern these processes. By delving into the molecular and systemic intricacies of the human body, we aim to cultivate a community of well-informed individuals who can apply scientific theory to practical training, thereby achieving optimal results in personal health, athletic performance, and a biological understanding.

name: Spartan Upcycle
summary: Create more, and waste less with Spartan Upcycle, the creative reuse branch of the MSU Surplus Store & Recycling Center. We host hands-on DIY and arts/crafts events that give you the chance to reuse, repurpose, and reimagine discarded materials. Join us for Student Upcycle Fridays and other events! View our Events Details Page and follow @spartanupcycle and @msu_recycling for updates and recap photos. Spartan Upcycle encourages all of us to rethink traditional definitions of value and purpose, challenge ourselves and empower each other to take creative risks, and ultimately discover a new use for items that were once thought of as waste. Are you a student looking to hold a crafting event? Source materials from us! Submit a request here .

name: Spartan Bookstore
summary: THE BEST PLACE FOR TEXTBOOKS We work directly with faculty to ensure we have the right materials We carry every book and supporting material you’ll need – other places only carry the most popular titles Options: Rental, digital, used or new – choose the format that best suits your needs…and budget Use financial aid funds and Sparty Cash in-store and online Order online and pick up in-store for free We price match against Amazon and most local competitors.* Find a cheaper advertised price within seven days, and we’ll give you the difference on a gift card. We buy back new and used textbooks year-round and give you cash back. We are your store from orientation through graduation! Rental books cost less than new books. Use it. Highlight in it. Write in it. Return it. What are the book rental rules? Create a book rental profile and provide some personal info. and a credit card as collateral – we will charge you for the book if you don’t return it. You can highlight and take notes in rented

name: Academic Excellence Student Group
summary: The Academic Excellence Student Group is dedicated to improving the educational experience of students at every level by streamlining the integration of third-party resources, independent study plans, and faculty-created learning materials.

name: MCAT Club, MSU
summary: The MCAT Club is to provide pre-med students at Michigan State University with resources and support for MCAT preparation, including access to free and paid materials, study groups, and expert advice.

name: Society of Plastics Engineers Michigan State University Student Chapter
summary: SPE’s MSU Student Chapter is a student led organization that seeks to educate, promote, recognize, and communicate technical accomplishments for all phases of plastics and plastic based-composite developments – particularly in the automotive industry. Topic areas include applications, materials, processing, equipment, tooling, design, and development.

name: TransAction
summary: TransAction seeks to build a sense of community among MSU students who are transgender, nonbinary, and/or gender non-conforming, as well as to defend their rights and advocate for their specific social, educational, and cultural needs. These students often face harassment, hostility, and discrimination in every area of their lives, including when interacting with the university. A supportive network will help combat the transphobia, cissexism, transmisogyny, and isolation that these students frequently experience. Regular meetings are held weekly in collaboration with Transcend and tend to be focused on community building with activities such as painting, presentation night, self-care, board game night, and more! Larger scale events vary from year to year but usually take place throughout the semester. Office hours are held at least once per week and as e-board availability allows, providing access to another community space with free gender affirming materials, snacks, the transform c

name: RHO EPSILON IOTA
summary: The purpose of Rho Epsilon Iota is to foster the ideals of honesty, equality, representation, knowledge, and professionalism in all facets of real estate. These ideals are reflected in the fraternal programs for which its members and auxiliary groups can actively learn and engage in real estate acquisitions, professional appraisals, fund management, residential licensure, continuing education, community outreach, networking, and commercial development, and architectural creation/design.

name: Labor and Employment Relations Association MSU Student Affiliate
summary: The Labor and Employment Relations Association (LERA) is the singular organization in the country where professionals interested in all aspects of labor and employment relations network to share ideas and learn about new developments, issues, and practices in the field. The LERA chapter at Michigan State University is a student association that works to provide a platform for the latest information regarding labor, employment, and industrial relations news and trends through presentations from Human Resource professionals as well as periodicals distributed through social media mediums. Our mission is to cultivate an innovative community of professionals and scholars who are committed to transforming the workplace through inclusive dialogue, education, and advocacy. We aim to enrich our members' understanding and expertise through targeted skill-building workshops, engaging events, and meaningful networking opportunities. By fostering a space where varied perspectives are valued and hea
